There are currently thousands of Turkish citizens taking part in a 250 mile march to Istanbul. It is expected that the number of marchers will grow as they approach the city. However, it is unlikely this will have much of an impact on Mr. Erdogan. Since the attempted coup last summer, the government has made an estimated 50,000 arrests. The President's grip on power has only grown since the attempted coup, bolstered by the results of a recent referendum. It is extremely unlikely Erdogan will step down or be removed before August 1st.

Decomposition:
1/ Will internal opposition generate a successful attempt at overthrowing Erdogan before 1 Aug 2017?
2/ Will a foreign power with sufficient influence attempt, overtly or covertly, to overthrow Erdogan?
3/ Will Erdogan concede power formally to decrease domestic/foreign pressure by installing a proxy as president?
4/ Will "Gezi Park"-like protests be generated by a trigger, and be sufficient for unseating Erdogan? 4b/ Is there any scheduled political event before 1 Aug that could act as a platform, or a trigger?
5/ Will Kurdish or jihadist terrorism sufficiently increase in Turkey to pressure Erdogan for resigning?

There are 3 ways this could happen: 
1. He dies. Erdogan is 62 so this is unlikely. Poisoning or assassination are a possibility but again unlikely. 
2. He is kicked out in another coup. Given the failure of the recent coup, this is highly unlikely. 
3. A transfer of power. Even if Erdogan called a snap election it is hard to imagine him losing. 
Giving each roughly 1% chance of happening. So 3%

However, he is more and more trying to undermine any legacy created by the Kemalists and this may cause further rupture among different parts of Turkey's political elite. He may not seem as secure as he seems but his power is still very strong.

Butler, (2016), states that:

Tayyip Erdogan is in strong position. The reaction from the public to the coup showed that he is strongly supported, and appears to have cleansed many adversaries or gained the upper hand, for the time being at least. It is unimaginable that he will wish to step down before the next Presidential elections in 2019. There is a small probability of not making 01/08/2017 as President, due to health reasons or accident. So, it remains the possibility of assassination, and It is a very rare event for politicians to get assassinated.

Without a presidential election in the coming year and having consolidated power after the failed coup, the most serious threat for Erdogan is being assassinated or dying of other causes. The probability of dying in the next year for a 62 year old male seems to be 1.24% (http://life-span.healthgrove.com/l/63/62). Having made quite some enemies over the past year (the GÃ¼len movement, the PKK, IS and probably parts of the military still) I would estimate the chances of him being killed in the next year at ~ 2%.

Erdogan's position isn't under threat but there is a risk of physical problems, another coup or a smoking gun to show that the coup was staged. Moreover, Turkish population currently supports him but this might change quickly if an economic crisis occurs

According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Erdogan's resilience (read: mastery of internal security) and strategic positioning between NATO and Russia all work in his favor.
The other options for removal are also unlikely. Erdogan will never resign. His health seems good; barring some low-probability event, he won't be forced to resign for health reasons.

Erdogan has consolidated his power over the past few years, and the recent coup attempt has caused him to redouble his efforts. He has detained, fired and imprisoned tens of thousands of government employees and has essentially wiped out the top ranks of the military. The top ranks of the order of battle for Turkey's military has been nearly completely emptied of active personnel: https://foreignpolicymag.files.wordpress.com/2016/08/turkish-land-forces-partial-order-of-battle-july-2016-01-copy.png, for instance. That makes any coup attempt originating in the military extremely unlikely. It is also unlikely that he would be defeated in an election, if one were to be held, because of his very high popularity among rural populations, which make up a high percentage of voters in Turkey. An assassination attempt is possible, although security around Erdogan is certainly going to continue to be very tight.
Still in control of all the apparatus
His oposition was wikend so he is stronger now
He will successfully consolidate his power, and hold on to it.

The failed coup attempt forced Erdogan to make a choice on the chessboard: does he want to Turkey to be a pawn in the anti-Western coalition of countries throughout the world or will he seek closer ties with the EU and the US? For Erdogan, the choice is the former. The likelihood of closer ties with Europe (EU membership) have always been slim. And ties with the US have been disintegrating for over a decade. In addition, you cannot carry out purges without the expected cries of "human rights!" from the West. That said, it does seem like Erdogan chose his side of the chessboard a few years ago. His turn against the EU and the US has been evolving and increasing in intensity over time. 
So, it's back to Russia.

His political maneuver around the failed coup against him and follow-up large-scale political arrests of anyone suspected being in opposition has boosted his power significantly and created empathy among Turkish population. According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Erdogan had a notable grip on power even before the coup. After he purged tens of thousands of those suspected of involvement, it only grew stronger.
He could exit office for any of the following reasons:
Not with Putin watching his back and relations with Israel starting to improve.  https://www.rt.com/news/355173-erdogan-putin-first-meeting/

The annual risk of death of a 55-65yr old man in the UK is 0.8% (no data for Turkey). I will adjust that down to half on the account of what is likely to be very regular and high quality medical care. So, 0.4% chance of natural death within a year.
Assassination is clearly possible and probably much more likely than natural causes. That said, he has probably been at risk for years already and most likely has an experienced and well informed security detail. I'd say about 2% chance of assassination within the year.
Chance of political overthrow is low. Certainly very unlikely that he would step down voluntarily. It's difficult to see the emergence of an effective opposition, but the situation is volatile. I'd say another 2% chance of this.  
I'll go with around 4% in total.
It will be some time before opposition forces can coalesce and organize to oust Erdogan, given the failure of the coup and his response. However assassination and a natural death are still possible.

Seems very unlikely given his political position after the failed coup, but the situation is still unsettling enough so cannot rule out further politically motivated violence against leadership, along with natural causes, like age and poor health.
Any coup will fail to have the support of the secular opposition parties, various Kurdish parties and of course Erdogan's supporters themselves.
He appears to be ruling with an Iron Hand.    During the failed coup, he called upon the populace to go to the streets on his behalf, and they did.

Events in today's Turkey are eerily similar to those that preceded the Spanish Civil War. A failed coup in 1932 led to its supporters being arrested and purged; a show of unity of all political forces saved the regime from falling for 4 years but unrest, terrorism, and extreme polarisation​ led the military to produce another coup, this time successful that led to the Civil War.

I predict there is only one event that will stop him from being Turkey's President before August 1, 2017: His death. And I don't think that will happen without war breaking out first. But with my prediction of the likelihood of that event, I don't think there will be war either.

Before the coup-attempt, there was some chance that people would react as Erdogan took more power. Now, Erdogan has been strengthened. The opposition is on the defensive, and the army has shown that it is not going to attempt a coup in a hurry. Erdogan has purged -- and thus weakened -- a lot of possible resistance. Of course he could still go of natural causes, or be assassinated but I think these probabilities are near-zero.
His term should end in 2019, after the failed coup attempt chances of a successful one are very small. So is the chance of him dying before before this date.
The President is selected for a term of office of five years, and can be re-elected only once. Wikipedia

Initial forecast, and no real confidence behind it. Erdogan is being ruthlessly autocratic, but is this an understandable - if extreme - response to last month's "treachery" or the actions of a man who now feels genuinely threatened? 
By this time next year, what will the neighboring region look like? Will the Kurds have their own state? Will ISIS have been overrun in Mosul and Raqqa, and if so, where will thousands of those defeated jihadists be heading? What effect might a post-Syria surge in migration have on Turkish society? Will Turkey divorce itself from the West? And just how far is Erdogan likely to go now that an aborted coup has given him the kind of power he's been hunting for years?
I fancy that accurate forecasting at this stage depends more on good luck than good judgement, but it's just too fascinating to leave alone. So, 20% to cover the likelihood of a Black Swan event, or a pattern which hasn't yet had time to show itself.

Erdogan enjoys widespread public support - even in Istanbul - and seems to be quite ruthless in purging certain elements of his "enemies" (Gulenists), while other main opposition elements (Kemalists) remain far weaker than was the case prior to the period of AKP rule (and purges undertaken in the army over thhe past decade), while the other principal opposition element (Kurdish forces) is under physical assault from the state. He is in a very strong position: it would take very substantial reverses (of a kind more or less unprecedented in modern Turkey) to lead to his removal as President in the timespan under consideration. It looks rather as though the construction of something far more like a dictatorship than has existed hitherto may be underway.
